importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the most recent update on the military's crackdown at KK Park, signaling ongoing tensions and enforcement actions in Myanmar’s conflict zones.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 2021 military coup in Myanmar triggered a civil war and led to the rise of armed opposition groups and scam centres as hubs of organized crime and human exploitation.
The 2025 raid at KK Park reflects the current phase of military operations targeting transnational criminal networks operating in conflict-prone border regions.

keyTakeAways: The Myanmar military arrested over 2,198 people, including 445 women and 1,645 men, in a raid on KK Park, a major scam centre on the Thai-Myanmar border.
KK Park, located in Myawaddy Township, Kayin State, was used by criminal syndicates for illegal gambling, money laundering, and online romance and investment scams.
The raid involved operations across 250 low-rise buildings including warehouses and shophouses, indicating a vast and complex network of criminal activity.

The military seized 30 Starlink satellites — built by SpaceX and operated under Elon Musk — which are used to maintain internet connectivity in remote or power-cut conditions, suggesting a technological edge for criminal operations.
Senior leaders of the Karen National Union, an armed group opposing the military, were reportedly involved in scam operations at KK Park, linking military conflict with organized crime.
The scam centre has drawn international attention, especially after Chinese actor Wang Xing was trafficked and rescued in January 2025, raising global concern over human trafficking and exploitation.
Thai police estimate up to 100,000 people work in scam operations along the Thai-Myanmar border, many of whom are victims of human trafficking and forced labor.
The United States Department of the Treasury sanctioned over 20 companies and individuals in Myanmar and Cambodia in September 2025 for involvement in scam-related criminal operations.
Myanmar and China have been under pressure to curb scam activities, with China particularly vocal due to the trafficking case involving Wang Xing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant military operation on October 21, 2025, Myanmar’s armed forces arrested over 2,198 individuals — including 445 women and 1,645 men — at KK Park, a notorious scam centre located in Myawaddy Township, Kayin State, just across the border from Thailand’s Mae Sot. The facility, spanning over 250 low-rise buildings, was used by international criminal syndicates for illegal gambling, money laundering, and online romance and investment scams. Authorities seized 30 Starlink satellites, a key technology enabling internet access in remote areas, linking the operation to broader issues of digital criminal infrastructure. Senior leaders of the Karen National Union, an armed opposition group, are reportedly tied to the scam operations, illustrating how armed conflict and organized crime intersect. The crackdown comes amid growing international pressure from Thailand and China, especially after the 2025 case involving Chinese actor Wang Xing, who was trafficked into a scam centre. Human rights groups report that many employees are victims of human trafficking, lured by false employment promises and subjected to forced labor. The United States has also responded by sanctioning over 20 individuals and companies in Myanmar and Cambodia for scam-related activities, underscoring global efforts to combat transnational crime in Southeast Asia.
title: Myanmar military arrests more than 2,000 people at infamous scam centre
